unnormalised: The Inland Waterways Authority of India (IWAI) has announced plans to develop enhanced infrastructure along National Waterway 1 (NW-1), the Ganga-Bhagirathi-Hooghly river system, by Q3 2025. The project aims to improve navigation and cargo transportation between Haldia and Prayagraj, a distance of approx. 1620 km. Investments of over Rs. 1000 crore are expected to boost the capacity of existing terminals and establish new facilities.
normalised: The Inland Waterways Authority of India (I-W-A-I) has announced plans to develop enhanced infrastructure along National Waterway one (N-W-one), the Ganga-Bhagirathi-Hooghly river system, by Q three two thousand and twenty five. The project aims to improve navigation and cargo transportation between Haldia and Prayagraj, a distance of approximately one thousand six hundred and twenty kilometer. Investments of over rupee one thousand crore are expected to boost the capacity of existing terminals and establish new facilities.

unnormalised: The initiative includes dredging operations to maintain a minimum draft of 3 meters, as well as the installation of night navigation aids and River Information Systems (RIS). This will enable 24/7 operations and reduce transit times for vessels carrying goods like coal, iron ore, and agricultural products. Key ports along NW-1, such as Kolkata Port Trust and the Varanasi terminal, are slated for upgrades.
normalised: The initiative includes dredging operations to maintain a minimum draft of three meter, as well as the installation of night navigation aids and River Information Systems (R-I-S). This will enable twenty four divided by seven operations and reduce transit times for vessels carrying goods like coal, iron ore, and agricultural products. Key ports along N-W-one, such as Kolkata Port Trust and the Varanasi terminal, are slated for upgrades.

unnormalised: According to a statement released on 16/11/2024, the development of NW-1 aligns with the government's Sagarmala Programme, aiming to promote coastal shipping and inland waterways as cost-effective and eco-friendly modes of transportation. The IWAI anticipates a significant increase in cargo volume, potentially reaching 20 million tonnes per annum by 2030, generating substantial economic benefits for the region.
